nodes.text: A common starting point for forecasting is the
A forecasting method that assumes that as sales grow, many income statement and balance sheet items will grow, remaining the same percent of sales.
assumes that as sales grow, many income statement and balance sheet items will grow, remaining the same percent of sales. For example,
shows that KMS’s costs excluding depreciation were 78% of sales in 2019. There were sales of $74,889 (in thousands). If KMS forecasts that sales will grow by 18% in 2020, then:

nodes.text: For ease of exposition, we will base our forecast on a single year, 2019. Companies often take into account averages and trends over several years in forecasting for the future.

metadata.caption: Note: In this table and elsewhere in the chapter, we display rounded numbers. Calculations are based on the actual numbers in the spreadsheet with all significant digits. As a result, there will occasionally be a small discrepancy between the Excel-calculated value shown and the hand-calculated value using the rounded numbers displayed.

config.caption: Note: In this table and elsewhere in the chapter, we display rounded numbers. Calculations are based on the actual numbers in the spreadsheet with all significant digits. As a result, there will occasionally be a small discrepancy between the Excel-calculated value shown and the hand-calculated value using the rounded numbers displayed.
config.credit: *NM indicates representing the item as a percent of sales is not meaningful.
config.activityTitle: KMS Designs’ 2019 Income Statement and Balance Sheet

nodes.text: We are essentially assuming that KMS will maintain its profit margins as its sales revenues grow. We proceed by making similar assumptions about working capital items on the balance sheet such as cash, accounts receivable, inventory, and accounts payable. The far-right column of

shows what percent of sales each of these items was in 2019. We can use those percentages to forecast part of the balance sheet in 2020. For example, if sales grow to $88,369 as we predict, then our inventory will need to grow to

nodes.text: Some of the items in the percent of sales column are marked “NM” for “Not Meaningful.” For example, our assets and accounts payables might reasonably be expected to grow in line with sales, but our long-term debt and equity will not naturally grow in line with sales. Instead, the change in equity and debt will reflect choices we make about dividends and net new financing.

metadata.caption: Note: In this table and elsewhere in the chapter, we display rounded numbers. Calculations are based on the actual numbers in the spreadsheet with all significant digits. As a result, there will occasionally be a small discrepancy between the Excel-calculated value shown and the hand-calculated value using the rounded numbers displayed.
